channel.title: Does this not justify the death penalty?
channel.description:
Be warned, this is incredibly disturbing.
http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-15267792

item.title: Does this not justify the death penalty?
item.dc:creator: @bootnecklad bootnecklad
item.description:
@bootnecklad wrote:

Moparisthebest:

Of course it justifies the death penalty, any time someone kills another person out of anything except an accident or self-defense they should be killed. Doing so may deter others from murdering others, but will 100% definitely stop them from killing again, something no other form of punishment can guarantee.

Would it not be a greater and harsher punishment to put such offenders in prisons and make them work for the rest of their lives? If they want a meal at the end of the day they have to work and pay for it (Obviously they work within the prisons. Knowing you are here for the rest of your life is a definate punishment.

In an idealised world then the inmates could be taught and eventually brought back into society. But only if they pass all relevant tests within the prison to make sure that their mental state and what not is in order.

I could go into more detail because I can’t be bothered and I want see what you say to this first. :>

Read full topic
item.source: Does this not justify the death penalty?

item.title: Does this not justify the death penalty?
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

Moparisthebest: You said ANYONE that killed someone, except for self-defense/accident should be killed?
Wouldn’t this end in a killing loop, or should we apply double standard?

Isn’t you against big government? A government with the power over life and death isn’t small.

[quote=“mwiebelhaus, post:22, topic:417946”][quote author=Newty link=topic=520495.msg3780426#msg3780426 date=1318434320]
Bowser jr obviously lives in a fantasy world where 1st world countries can afford to bring 3rd world countries out of poverty.

Protip: We can’t, we shouldn’t have to, and we shouldn’t want to. The vast majority of so called 1st world countries can’t even end poverty in our own countries so we should be focusing within our own borders…
[/quote]

Agreed, many of the problems lie with the government of these countries trying to keep the people oppressed. Much aid that we do give to impoverished countries never reaches to people. But you guys want the US to keep to their own business and not interfere with other countries so the US shouldn’t worry about it (not that I wouldn’t want to do this anyway because it would put our economy in a much worse state spending more of foreign aid).[/quote]
Do you know why foreign aid doesn’t work?
Because imperialist countries get 6 times the money back because of illegitimate loans in the past.

Read full topic
item.source: Does this not justify the death penalty?

item.title: Does this not justify the death penalty?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:20, topic:417946”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=520495.msg3781081#msg3781081 date=1318472524]
Of course it justifies the death penalty, any time someone kills another person out of anything except an accident or self-defense they should be killed. Doing so may deter others from murdering others, but will 100% definitely stop them from killing again, something no other form of punishment can guarantee.
[/quote]
How do you execute someone by an accident or self-defense?[/quote]
Where did I say ‘execute’? I clearly said ‘kill’, and you should be able to see how you could kill someone accidentally or in self-defense, right?

Read full topic

Protip: We can’t, we shouldn’t have to, and we shouldn’t want to. The vast majority of so called 1st world countries can’t even end poverty in our own countries so we should be focusing within our own borders…[/quote]

item.source: Does this not justify the death penalty?

item.title: Does this not justify the death penalty?
item.dc:creator: @MujaheD Radeon
item.description:
@MujaheD wrote:

This isn’t a problem restricted to Africa or third world countries, the same journalist did an investigation in the UK to find that it also occurs there. Poverty might make you steal but I don’t think it will push you to commit such horrible acts.

The problem I see here, is the superstitious belief in black magic etc. Religions long ago executed people for committing black magic, whether it involves murder or not. Whilst these practises have largely withdrawn from society, there is a real possibility that it may return to popular culture as it is already.

Read full topic
item.source: Does this not justify the death penalty?

item.title: Does this not justify the death penalty?
item.dc:creator: @bloodrayne bloodrayne
item.description:
@bloodrayne wrote:

The only problem is, they don’t see it as doing anything wrong. I’m sure it’s a cultural thing that they’ve done for hundreds or thousands of years, and to them it’s a good thing because it brings good luck or whatever it is they want.

It’s cultural, just like child brides in India and cannibalism in Papua New Guinea. Others see it as terrifying, but unfortunately, it’s not terrifying to them and they’ll continue to do it.

Read full topic

item.source: Does this not justify the death penalty?

item.title: Does this not justify the death penalty?
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

To simply say, “Let’s end protectionism!” isn’t going to do much. In fact, protectionism is the logical reaction to economic neoliberalism and the Free Trade movement. While ideally it makes sense, Free Trade is only free for the “best”, and in practice is little more than creating a legal description for what most would call wage slavery by corrupt multinational corporations.

Read full topic
item.source: Does this not justify the death penalty?

item.title: Does this not justify the death penalty?
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

Africa is still far behind. This used to be daily business in Europe too, but that’s ages ago. People in Africa kept to their own rituals, because they didn’t have a revolution similar to our Neolithic revolution. Well, they had, but didn’t take it that far because Africa generally isn’t as fertile as Europe, the Middle East or America. Hunter/gatherers don’t have time to think about spiritual concepts, so they stick to natural religions.

Read full topic

item.title: Does this not justify the death penalty?
item.dc:creator: @Greeny Greeny
item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

Africa (or certain parts of) is still full of witch hunts, cannibalism and genocide. I haven’t read through all the posts in this thread yet but the people of these countries do these things for lack of education and don’t deserve to die for it. Unfortunately traditions and rituals are dangerous things.

item.title: Does this not justify the death penalty?
item.dc:creator: @Thebeanie TheBeanie
item.description:
@Thebeanie wrote:

What about this, In south africa a black guy broke into a white south africans house, and macheted to death a mother and her two children. When he saw the father had a shotgun he ran and tried jumping over the wall, The father shot the black guy as he was trying to jump over the wall and because he had his back to him he got done for murder.

Read full topic
item.source: Does this not justify the death penalty?

item.title: Does this not justify the death penalty?
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

Newty: First of all we can end protectionism, and let the countries trade with the 1st world.

Second we should encourage them to build up their own corporations, and NOT let rich multinational corporation exploit their country. And encourage them to have strict control of their own natural resources. The best would be to let state owned corporations dig up the valuables, and use the money to build the country.

Third: We can delete debt that never should had been given. (Pocket money for dictators). And if we give them new loans or aid, it must be on their premise, not ours. (Not force them to become our prostitute).

Fourth: Remove embargo against Cuba and other countries.

Fifth: Prioritize getting them out of poverty and give them a better life, and not on removing all those dictators we don’t like.

The first world got rich by exploiting the rest, it is time to fix the problem. Poverty is very often the reasons for crimes, death penalty have no effect there.

Read full topic

item.title: Does this not justify the death penalty?
item.dc:creator: @MujaheD Radeon
item.description:
@MujaheD wrote:

Bowser jr:

Radeon; If I should support death penalty it would be against leaders that have caused 10.000+ deaths. Like Bush and Donald Rumsfeld, by sending them to death row you would show the ultimate condemnation over their actions. This case in North-Africa is nothing.

I value this opinion for the first part, but this particular case I think is also horrific. Not sure if you watched the video, but it really upset me emotionally.

Read full topic
